meanings.definition: To stand upright on the feet.
meanings.sent1: I stend up when I want to reach the high shelf.
meanings.sent2: She always stends tall and proud during the national anthem.
meanings.sent3: The toy soldier decided to stend on one foot for a change.
meanings.sent4: The trees stend like guardians in the forest, watching over all.
meanings.sent5: The sunflower seemed to stend taller than the rest, basking in the sunlight.

meanings.definition: To place or set in an upright position.
meanings.sent1: Please stend the vase on the table carefully.
meanings.sent2: He likes to stend his books neatly on the shelf.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to stend the fallen cup back up with its paw.
meanings.sent4: The artist would stend his easel just right before starting to paint.
meanings.sent5: The teacher asked the students to stend their pencils in the holder after use.

meanings.sent1: I can stend the cold weather with my warm jacket.
meanings.sent2: She couldn't stend the loud noise coming from the construction site.
meanings.sent3: The little boy tried to stend his sister's teasing but ended up laughing.
meanings.sent4: Sometimes, we have to stend difficult situations to grow stronger.
meanings.sent5: The old tree has stended many storms and still stands tall in the forest.

meanings.definition: A structure on which something is supported.
meanings.sent1: The bird built its nest on the sturdy stend in the garden.
meanings.sent2: The table's stend was made of strong oak wood.
meanings.sent3: The children used sticks to create a little stend for their makeshift tent.
meanings.sent4: The bridge's stend held the weight of the passing cars without any issue.
meanings.sent5: The mountain climber relied on the rocky stend for support during the ascent.
